reviewText: I can never ever, get enough of Agatha Christies Poirot.  I'm so in love with this character.I wish this program was on today.  Instead of some of the trash of reality tv on the telly.Thank you, Lennis, Seattle

reviewText: I'm very dissatisfied with this collection of Poirot mysteries. In "Plymouth Express" Poirot pulls the solution of the mystery right out of a hat -- no chance for the viewer to even make a guess.Weak, very weak indeed.The production values are up to the usual high standards but the plots of all 3 of these mysteries are extremely flimsy.On a positive note, it makes avoiding the $24 purchase all the easier for those who luckily have not made the purchase yet.Maybe they did us a favor sticking 3 clunkers on one DVD.

reviewText: "Poirot Collector's Set 4" includes three 50-minute episodes from Series 3 of the ITV television program, which originally aired in 1991: "The Million Dollar Bond Robbery", "The Plymouth Express", and "Wasps' Nest". Unlike the previous two series, these screenplays were not written by Clive Exton. "The Million Dollar Bond Robbery" was dramatized by Anthony Horowitz. David Suchet's portrayal of the dapper little Belgian gent who can solve any crime is, as usual, charming and a pleasure to watch. Hercule Poirot is assisted by his much slower friend Capt. Arthur Hastings (Hugh Fraser) and his stylish and efficient secretary Miss Lemon (Pauline Moran). Inspector Japp (Philip Jackson) of Scotland Yard is not in "The Million Dollar Bond Robbery" but does feature in the other two episodes. This is a nice combination of crimes -a robbery, a murder, and a murder that has not yet happened:"The Million Dollar Bond Robbery" finds Capt. Hastings gushing over the imminent first voyage of the Queen Mary when Poirot receives a letter from a Mr. Vavasour (Ewan Hooper) of the London and Scottish Bank. Due to an attempt on the life of the bank's joint General Manager Mr. Shaw (David Quilter), Vavasour fears that there will be an attempt to steal $1 million in Liberty Bonds that Mr. Shaw is entrusted to carry to New York. The much younger Mr. Philip Ridgeway (Olivier Parker) is to make the journey instead, and his fiancee (Natalie Ogle) is terribly worried about his safety. So Poirot and Hastings are to accompany Ridgeway and the bonds on the maiden voyage of the Queen Mary. Poirot gets out the big guns to combat his seasickness on this one.Poirot is not impressed when the wealthy owner of an Australian mining company, Mr. Halliday (John Stone), tries to hire him to get rid of his daughter Florence's (Shelagh McLeod) suave French suitor, the Compte de Rocheforte (Alfredo Michelson), in "The Plymouth Express". Halliday is beside himself with annoyance at Florence's gambling estranged husband Rupert (Julian Wadham) and the Compte who seems to only want his daughter's money. But when Florence catches the train to go away for the weekend, accompanied by her maid and her entire jewel case, the situation takes a turn for the tragic. Both of Florence's suitors needed money and both are suspect in this case, one of the few in Christie's oeuvre that has emotional impact.The "Wasps' Nest" in question is in the garden of John Harrison (Martin Turner), a writer and the son of one of Poirot's first friends in England. Poirot runs into Harrison at a village festival, where he is accompanied by his fashion model fiancee Molly Deane (Melanie Jessup). Poirot is not in a cheerful mood, as he hasn't had a case in a few weeks, and seemingly innocent but odd circumstances stir his suspicions. He comes to believe that a crime will be committed. In hopes of preventing a murder, he sets out to investigate the crime before it takes place. Meanwhile, Hastings is enjoying his new photography hobby, which comes in handy on the case. And we get to see a 1930s fashion show staged.The DVD (Acorn 2003): Bonus features are a text interview with David Suchet that appears on all of the Collector's Set discs, as well as the usual short text bio of Agatha Christie and list of Poirot books. There filmographies for 9 actors and a "Who played Poirot?" essay that tells us who has portrayed the detective in films 1931-2001.
summary: Nice Selection of Three 50-minute Episodes from Poirot's Series 3.
